awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Understanding Novae as Shock-Powered Explosions
awd_abstract_narration:
Novae explosions are responsible for the sudden appearance and gradual fading of light from a previously unknown star. They are known to be produced by binary systems (two stars orbiting each other) in which one of the stars is a "white dwarf". These stars are extremely dense, with a mass similar to the Sun's compressed into an object the size of the Earth.  When material is stripped from the companion star and transferred to the surface of the white dwarf, a powerful explosion can occur.  This team will use a modern survey to find novae and to follow up with detailed measurements using radio, optical/IR, and space based telescopes.  This will result in a deeper understanding of novae and the processes that cause them. An educational program will be developed for rural 5-19 year olds in astronomy and physical sciences working with the Michigan 4H. The MSU Observatory will host an Astronomy Club with monthly meetings and sponsor members to develop independent projects for the County Fair. 

This program will review the present data and obtain a complete and unbiased sample of nova using a modern sky survey.  They will also monitor this sample with gamma-ray through radio observations.  High-resolution radio measurements will trace the evolution of the ejecta, leading to further insight about the conditions and phenomena that produce novae. This research will 1) Establish the first comprehensive and well-defined sample of Galactic novae, 2) Determine which novae are shock-powered by observing them with the gamma-ray telescope Fermi/LAT and HWAC, 3) Image novae ejecta with high resolution capable radio arrays to map distribution of thermal ejecta and pinpoint the location of synchrotron-emitting shocks in order to determine if nova morphology is set by a universal mechanism or if variations in ejecta geometry are linked to variations in shock powering shaping.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Classical novae are very common, garden-variety explosions which take place on the surfaces of white dwarf stars accreting from companions, with about 10 discovered each year in our Galactic backyard. This NSF CAREER program has helped usher in a fundamental shift in the way we view novae, from ballistic explosions which simply reprocess the luminous emission from the hot central white dwarf, to dynamic, multi-phase explosions where shocks internal to the ejecta dictate the energetics and multi-wavelength signatures. Key results of this program include:

--A stunning correlation between the GeV gamma-ray and optical light curves for nova V906 Car, showing that the same process that produces the gamma-rays (shocks) must also be producing the bulk of the total luminosity of the nova.

--An exploration of the X-ray behavior of novae while they are producing gamma-rays. We showed that typically, softer X-rays are absorbed and non-detected, while harder X-rays are detectable with NuSTAR, but surprisingly, they are orders of magnitude fainter than expected from simple models. We are actively working with our theorist colleagues to understand and model this discrepancy.

--Searches for very high-energy (TeV) gamma-rays from novae with the HAWC telescope, and further multi-wavelength studies of the first nova detected at TeV energies, RS Oph.

--A survey of the multi-frequency radio behavior of novae, demonstrating that most show thermal emission while about a quarter show non-thermal synchrotron emission produced by relativistic electrons accelerated in shocks.

--An Annual Reviews Article summarizing our changing understanding of novae since gamma-rays were detected from them in 2010.

--The most robust estimate of the Galactic nova rate to date, measured using two all-sky optical surveys (ASAS-SN and Gaia) and forming the centerpiece of the Ph.D. dissertation of Adam Kawash. We find that 26 +/- 5 novae explode in our Milky Way Galaxy each year.

--Engaging a large number of undergraduate students in observing novae and related stars at our local campus MSU Observatory, which hosts a 24 inch optical telescope.

For the Broader Impacts portion of this proposal, the PI’s team engaged school-age youth from rural backgrounds through Michigan 4-H, leading programs at the residential Exploration Days and hosting 4-H activity nights at MSU Observatory. This NSF CAREER program also supported the sustenance and expansion of our public programming at MSU Observatory, which hosts ~1500–3000 members of the public each year at public nights, open houses with hands-on activities for all ages, and special events for celestial special occasions like eclipses.
